module.p:
English both is a universal pronoun with dual number, equivalent in meaning to the two –
both of the apples
both of these/my apples
both of those/us/you/them A number of synonymous reduced forms are also possible –
both the apples, both apples
both these/my apples
both [are fine] An alternative, quasi-adverbial usage is also found –
the/these/my apples are both red
those/we/you/they both appeared

both can also be used to emphasise a conjunction –
Both Mary and Rachel knocked.

When talking about people, Gaelic translates both using an dithis –
an dithis sgoilearan both (of the) students
an dithis fhear sin both (of) those men
an dithis againn both of us
[thàinig] an dithis both [came]

For other things, Gaelic uses an dà (with cuid fem. measure, part, portion as the default noun) –
an dà ubhal both (of the) apples
an dà chù sin both (of) those dogs
an dà chuid both (of them)
TYGD: adv. le chèile; both great and small eadar bheag is mhòr.

Watson: 1. (of things, action etc.) gach cuid f, an dà chuid, gach; give me both sugar and salt thoir dhomh gach cuid siùcar is salann; meat or cheese? both! feòil no càise? an dà chuid! you/one can’t drink and drive chan fhaod thu / chan fhaodar an dà chuid dràibheadh agus òl; 2. (of people) le chèile, nan dithis; ; both of you an dithis agaibh; 3. (before adjs) eadar; they came both small and great thàinig iad, eadar bheag agus mhòr; 4. (as adj) gach, on both sides air gach taobh.
MacLennan: both adj. le chéile, ’n an dithis, araon; both conj araon, cuideachd, le chéile
Stòr-dàta: both adj. an dà chuid, le chèile, nan dithis.
